APIs and Loose Coupling

APIs and Loose Coupling Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(6) APIs are more than Technology

  • Clean separation of what and how
    • APIs define what to use as network-level interfaces
    • APIs do not define how these interfaces are implemented
  • Technically, an API defines how to interact with a capability
    • Messages sent across a network that allow applications to communicate
    • The API is the interface and provides access to a product [APIs Deliver Value [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VNwAYyfQ8Bw&list=UUDD75qoXHJSz4pv0o3WcTUw] (1)]
    • Applications can collaborate using the API language [What is an API? It's a Language! [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wDYeU2T4v2o&list=UUDD75qoXHJSz4pv0o3WcTUw] (1)]
    • APIs are a promise [What is an API? It's a Promise! [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gFu7CQKmBeQ&list=UUDD75qoXHJSz4pv0o3WcTUw] (1)] to make capabilities accessible
  • The goal of APIs is to establish loose coupling between various teams
    • APIs allow machines to communicate
    • Developers document/read APIs and can start collaborating (DX)
    • Users benefit from faster time-to-value for new products (UX)


APIs and Loose Coupling Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

APIs and Loose Coupling Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(10) Necessary but not Sufficient

  • APIs have been used for many decades
    • Local APIs have been used since the 1940s
    • Network APIs have been used since the 1950s
    • Network APIs used to be called Protocols
    • APIs are relatively new as an approach for Enterprise IT Architecture
  • APIs deliver most benefit when used for loose coupling
    1. Others (partners/public) can easily access APIs for collaboration
    2. Internal collaboration becomes easier (less coordination overhead)
    3. Mixed deployments are a natural architectural pattern with APIs
    4. Platform business models can leverage APIs for value co-creation


API Platforms

API Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(12) Jeff Bezos' API Mandate [https://gist.github.com/chitchcock/1281611]

  • Famous small set of SOA design rules
    • Teams must expose functionality through services
    • Communication happens only through service interfaces
    • Internal/external service is a matter of policy, not one of design
  • With more freedom comes more responsibility
    • Services must be documented and registered so that they can be discovered
    • Monitoring and metrics are necessary for finding root causes
    • All APIs must be hardened against DoS attacks
  • Much easier in today's technology landscape than in 2002


API Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(13) Two Perspectives: Internal and External APIs



API Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(14) APIs as External Interfaces

  • Direct API monetization
  • API foundation for user journeys (omni-channel)
  • Value chain optimization (outsourced APIs)


API Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(15) APIs as Internal Componentization

  • Moving from integration to interconnection (IT modernization)
  • Decoupling products and their development cycles and speed
  • Improving capability reuse across the whole organization


API Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(16) Unlock Existing Value: Open Everything



API Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(17) Got Strategy?

  • There is no one-size-fits-all API Strategy
  • Strategy always depends on context
    • What do you want to improve/achieve with APIs?
    • What does your organization look like?
    • What is the main value that you produce?
    • What do your customers look like?
    • What does your competition look like?


API Platforms Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(18) API Strategy = Pillars × Perspectives

External Internal
Biz
  • API monetization
  • Revenue-supporting APIs
  • Increase speed & feedback
  • Identify & stabilize enablers
  • Design for externalization
  • Increase biz insight with dashboards
Org
  • Focus on documentation/DX
  • Support discovery/self-service
  • Collect DX feedback
  • Products > projects (ownership)
  • Team enablement/support
  • Loose coupling for speed/agility
Tech
  • Tech trends and popularity
  • Invest in on-boarding support
  • Secure through platform
  • Loosely coupled implementations
  • Observe patterns and practices
  • Establish C4E for platform/support


Examples

Outline (Examples)

Examples Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(20) Dashboards

  • Gathering data from system/foundational APIs
  • Adding insights generated by process/analysis APIs
  • Exposing APIs that can be used for dashboard experiences
    • One possibility is to build dedicated Backends-for-Frontends (BFF) APIs
    • Another possibility is to build flexible APIs such as GraphQL


Examples Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(21) Big Data and AI

  • Big data and AI are two popular ways to create data-driven insights
  • Oftentimes data is available somewhere but hard to access
  • Exposing data makes it available to any kind of tooling/analysis
  • APIs allow to build multi-layered ways of creating and using insights


Conclusions

Outline (Conclusions)

Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms

(23) APIs and IT Architecture

  • APIs strictly speaking are simply network interfaces
  • APIs today are used to move towards more loosely couples architectures
  • Architectural changes need goals, a plan, and a result
    • API Strategy defines the goals of APIs at the strategic level
    • API Programs outlines how to achieve the goals and measure progress
    • API Platforms are the result of API programs


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): API Strategy, Programs, and Platforms
